summary.raw:
Tests scripts for isolating mpi startup problems on 2 nodes (32 cores) on Stampede.

This one hangs:

    ibrun -np 32 python3 startup_with_dedalus2_3d_hangs.py

This one works (as do any permutations where one or more grid resolutions are 256, including 256^3):

    ibrun -np 32 python3 startup_with_dedalus2_3d_works.py

so does a 2d problem:

    ibrun -np 32 python3 startup_with_dedalus2.py
summary.html:

summary.raw:
Working dgemm thread test (transform_thread_timing.py).

Auto-detects mac vs. linux and checks that numpy is linked against a
fast BLAS implementation for numpy.dot().

It's unclear right now whether mac os 10.9 is respecting the
veclib_maximum_threads setting.  Mac os results have been much, much
noisier than the stampede timings as well (though stampede login nodes
are much noisier than stampede idev nodes).  Also, speed scaling with
N_threads depends on N_transforms and shows some jagged and
non-intuitive behaviour even on stampede.

summary.raw:
Timing tests for effects of changing numbers of threads in a numpy instance.

To test the speed of numpy under a variety of thread counts:

    ./numpy_test_threads

Key point:

    To do a test like this, where the number of threads are controlled by an environment variable, is fairly tricky.  See `numpy_test_threads_no_joy` for an idea of how this can fail.  I've only gotten this test to work by doing an explicit subshell call through os.system().  Have open question on stackoverflow to see if there's a better way...

summary.raw:
Built spectral test for accuracy.

Inspired by Featherstone's accuracy plot.

Here we start in spectral space and do a coeff2grid, followed by
a grid2coeff transform.  We start with a full spectrum (either
ones or uniform random coeffs) and test whether error on
max|pre-post|.

Here we do the equivalent of a full spherical harmonic transform,
testing all m=[0,L_max] and all L within the triangular truncation.

--Ben Brown, 12/22/13

summary.raw:
Added (not-working) analytic test.  Played a bit with libsharp wrapper.

The pre and post transform grid values match, but the spectral power is completely wrong.  No idea what the source of this is yet.  Eigenfunctions test out fine (test_eigenfunction.py), so don't think we're doing transform with wrong polynomials.

--Ben Brown, 12/17/13, 6am

summary.raw:
Phenomenal.  We hold at 10^-14 vs. scipy up to m=84, l=[84,100].

We start have a nan problem at m=85, probably out of scipy, as we're
still bounded between +-1 with our normalized basis functions
(from LegendrePolynomial), but the multiplicative norm being applied
to scipy's values has exceed 10^(-150) at m=85.  Crazy!

In summary, we seem to be good.

Could try high wavenumber sympy, normalizing the result within the
arbitrary precision portion of the code.  Interesting idea, but will
be pretty slow.
--Ben Brown, 12/16/13, 3:20pm

summary.raw:
This one works.  Flipped definition of norm.

Made it a multiplication (division was fine too), and norming the
unnormalized P_LMs (from scipy or sympy) rather than blowing up the
normalized eigenfunctions (from our LegendrePolynomial object).

Fantastic!
--Ben Brown, 12/16/13, 3:05pm

summary.raw:
Big update to handle sympy eigenfunctions, do extended comparsion.

Strangely, our scipy comparison is now coming in at much higher
precision.  Namely, for lmax=340, n_grid=512, the error against scipy
is less than 10^-11.  This is great.  But what's different?  Unclear.
One difference (to test) I moved the norm to dividing the comparison
basis rather than amplifying the normalized basis.  In fact, I bet
that's it.

We have sympy eigenfunctions as well.  They compare very well with the
scipy basis functions (slightly different errors, sympy somewhat
lower, but within an order of magnitude).  Added ability to test large
and small wavenumber regimes, etc., only scipy, only sympy, etc.

--Ben Brown, 12/16/13, 3pm

summary.raw:
Added sympy basis functions.

We compare well with sympy basis functions.  As currently implemented,
the sympy evaluation is very, very slow compared to the scipy
evaluation.

Currently we can only compare against either sympy _or_ scipy.

--Ben Brown, 12/16/13, noon:30

summary.raw:
PMMT basis functions also look good.

As expected, since we didn't do any of the fancy magic from the
Fortran library (e.g., exploiting parity in the basis function
calculation, then folding the get the full range).

--Ben Brown, 12/16/13, noon

summary.raw:
Built plotter to test eigenfunctions.  Eigenfunctions look good.

Here we plot both the legendre poylnomial eigenfunctions as calculated
by our normalized recursion relationship (transform.basis_functions)
and also the relative error compared to the scipy.special associated
legendre polynomial calculation (lpmv).

For the MMTs, the errors are very small for small L and all m checked
so far (0-4).  They grow with increasing L, but it is unclear right
now whether that is a problem on our side or a problem on the scipy
library side.  I suspect the scipy library, as they are calculating
un-normalized P_LM, which will be more susceptible to the recursion
errors.  This will be important to test against other implementations
(e.g., the Wigner-d approach of Risbo 1996, or a sympy calculation).

This is a very promising start.  It looks like our calculated
polynomials _are_ associated legendre polynomials.

Time to check the PMMTs too.
--Ben Brown, 12/16/13, noon

summary.raw:
Built time_MMT_and_PMMT, which times over both transforms and does a grid-size loop.

Doing this, and standardizing output, for better comparison with
fortran Polynomial Transform library (which I did significant updates
to today).

Note: right now we go to 2048, which leads to a very long test.

--Ben Brown, 12/12/13, noon:15pm

summary.raw:
Did similar test for pre-refactor (default) and post-refactor.  Post wins, especially for PMMTs.

Added the pre and post profiling outputs, for use with pyprof2html.
Can be removed later.  Key data is that tottime spent in
236:_grid2coeff and 273:_coeff2grid has been shaved from 1.5/1.3 sec
to 0.58/0.43 sec.  Owing to this, PMMTs are about 30% faster than
before.  MMTs also a bit faster than before.

Overhead for PMMTs is still a bit high at this problem size; decreases
at larger problem sizes, but might be worth some attention.

PMMT overhead at Lmax=340, Ngrid=512 is ~25%; I think this is largely
in the np.add(), np.subtract() operations.

--Ben Brown, 12/11/13, 1pm

summary.raw:
Updated some docstrings, moved grid and basis computation to private.  Started PolynomialParallelPMMT.

Looks like I failed to commit this earlier.  In the interim,
I've also started implementing an algorithmic breakdown called
PolynomialParallelPMMT, which breaks the PMMT operation into
seperate and independent tasks where that seems most logical.

There are some possible memory contention issues to be wary of
in this current approach, but until we have an easy way to test
an openMP-like parallelism in python, it's all a bit academic.
--Ben Brown, 12/10/13, 10:40pm

summary.raw:
Shifted MMT/PMMT init routines into base classes and out of Legendre.

This leads to very clean structures for the LegendreMMT and
LegendrePMMT init routines.  Good improvement in readability
and good reduction in repeated code.

Top part of legendre_transform is still a rats nest, and a lot of doc
updating needs to occur.  May hold off until I have a better sense of
good doc style (tomorrow's task).

--Ben Brown, 12/10/13, 10:05pm

summary.raw:
Fixed slowdown bug in PMMT coeff2grid.  Now equal to grid2coeff.

Coeff2grid now also uses np.add and np.subtract.  Makes a factor of 2x
difference in overall overhead (now 2.2 seconds out of 17, vs. 4.5sec,
at Lmax=680, N_grid=1024).  Now coeff2grid PMMT takes the approx the
same amount of time as grid2coeff.

Passes test_legendre_transform.py

Also, moved timing wrappers back into one_legendre_transform and
time_legendre_transforms; namespace problem with passed test function.
--Ben Brown, 12/10/13, 3:50pm

summary.raw:
Propagating big refactoring exercise into legendre_transform.py

Now have a LegendrePolynomial object, which holds the basis function
computation, grid computation, weights computation, and everything
else we might need.

Note to self:
Might be useful to have the grids be their own objects that get pulled
in by the polynomial or the transform class.  Multiple inheritance is
cool.

--Ben Brown, 12/10/13, 3:05pm

summary.raw:
Further private variable logic in matrix_transform.py

Anything used internally in the transform (the coeff2grid_matrix,
the _sym and _asym variables, etc.) is now private.

Both grid_values and coeff_values are currently left public.

May change.
--Ben Brown, 12/10/13, 2:45pm

summary.raw:
Major cleanup of matrix_transform.py

Moving to a cleaner style, more analgous to YT's YTDataContainer style
as shared by Jeff.

https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/yt/src/09f43fdc818380523eb7445e8a3353f1e40ca1f6/yt/data_objects/data_containers.py?at=yt-3.0

Also more in line withm PEP-8:

http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008/

Adopting underscore weak private notation and a super class.

Legendre Transform will need to be modified to work with this new
approach.  In process now.
--Ben Brown, 12/10/13, 2:40pm

summary.raw:
Figured out problem: .T produces F-contiguous arrays.

The .flags on ndarrays was very helpful in sorting this out.
Transposes are forcing all arrays to be F-contiguous rather than
C-contiguous.  Time to figure out how to do a "real" transpose.

--Ben Brown, 12/9/13, 2:30pm

summary.raw:
MMTs now use same pre-compute logic as PMMTs.

There's an un-necessary copy operation on entry to both transforms,
but it's at least consistent with the PMMTs.

In the future, we may try pre-loading self.grid or self.coeff and
letting the other be set by transform ops only, as in other parts of
Dedalus.

--Ben Brown, 12/9/13, noon:30pm

--Ben Brown, 12/9/13, noon:30pm

values.message:
MMTs now use same pre-compute logic as PMMTs.

There's an un-necessary copy operation on entry to both transforms,
but it's at least consistent with the PMMTs.

In the future, we may try pre-loading self.grid or self.coeff and
letting the other be set by transform ops only, as in other parts of
Dedalus.

--Ben Brown, 12/9/13, noon:30pm

summary.raw:
Modified PMMTs now pass transform test

We pass the test_pmmt.py reduced script.

In the process I figured out that for the non-basis-func test
`test_function = (np.sin(P_LM_MMT.theta)**2)`, you need to have
L_max ~ 16, otherwise you'll fail the grid tests like no-ones
business.  Nice little test of convergence of representation :)

The dot products are still hacked (can't do performance-enhanced
version yet, with output as passed variable), and don't pass
legendre_transform_test.py test yet.

PMMTs pass one_legendre_transform.py, but MMTs do not.

--Ben Brown, 12/9/13, noon:20pm

summary.raw:
Removed 2 copies from grid2coeff, saved 10% time

Some of this is problem system variability.

before:
1000 	1.8128 	 0.0018 	  4.1447    0.0041	./matrix_transform.py : 168 ( grid2coeff )
after:
1000 	1.4307 	 0.0014 	  3.2538    0.0033 	./matrix_transform.py : 168 ( grid2coeff )

--Ben Brown, 12/7/13, 4pm

summary.raw:
PMMTs marginally faster than MMTs; progress!

faster than the MMTs, but it gives a path for progress!  I'll clean
this rats-nest of code up tomorrow when I can look at it cleanly.
